title: SEETrials: Leveraging Large Language Models for Safety and Efficacy Extraction in Oncology Clinical Trials
abstract: ABSTRACT Background Initial insights into oncology clinical trial outcomes are often gleaned manually from conference abstracts. We aimed to develop an automated system to extract safety and efficacy information from study abstracts with high precision and fine granularity, transforming them into computable data for timely clinical decision-making. Methods We collected clinical trial abstracts from key conferences and PubMed (2012-2023). The SEETrials system was developed with four modules: preprocessing, prompt modeling, knowledge ingestion and postprocessing. We evaluated the system’s performance qualitatively and quantitatively and assessed its generalizability across different cancer types— multiple myeloma (MM), breast, lung, lymphoma, and leukemia. Furthermore, the efficacy and safety of innovative therapies, including CAR-T, bispecific antibodies, and antibody-drug conjugates (ADC), in MM were analyzed across a large scale of clinical trial studies. Results SEETrials achieved high precision (0.958), recall (sensitivity) (0.944), and F1 score (0.951) across 70 data elements present in the MM trial studies Generalizability tests on four additional cancers yielded precision, recall, and F1 scores within the 0.966-0.986 range. Variation in the distribution of safety and efficacy-related entities was observed across diverse therapies, with certain adverse events more common in specific treatments. Comparative performance analysis using overall response rate (ORR) and complete response (CR) highlighted differences among therapies: CAR-T (ORR: 88%, 95% CI: 84-92%; CR: 95%, 95% CI: 53-66%), bispecific antibodies (ORR: 64%, 95% CI: 55-73%; CR: 27%, 95% CI: 16-37%), and ADC (ORR: 51%, 95% CI: 37-65%; CR: 26%, 95% CI: 1-51%). Notable study heterogeneity was identified (>75% I 2 heterogeneity index scores) across several outcome entities analyzed within therapy subgroups. Conclusion SEETrials demonstrated highly accurate data extraction and versatility across different therapeutics and various cancer domains. Its automated processing of large datasets facilitates nuanced data comparisons, promoting the swift and effective dissemination of clinical insights.

ABSTRACT  
 
Objective 
Conference abstracts provide preliminary evidence for clinical trial outcomes. This study aims to 
develop an automatic extraction system to precisely extract and convert granular safety and 
efficacy information from abstracts into a computable format for timely downstream analysis. 
 
Materials and Methods 
We collected multiple myeloma clinical trial abstracts from ASCO, ASH, and PubMed (2012-
2023) to develop SEETrials, a GPT-4 based system. Qualitative and quantitative evaluations 
were conducted. Descriptive data analysis on efficacy and safety entities was performed. The 
generalizability of the system was tested in three other cancer trial studies. 
 
Results 
SEETrials achieved precision, recall, and F1 of 95.5%, 93.9%, and 94.7% across 70 data 
elements. Analysis of 245 multiple myeloma clinical trial abstracts revealed variations in safety 
and efficacy entity distribution across different modalities and phases. Application to other 
cancer trial studies demonstrated consistent performance with precision, recall, and F1 of 96.9%, 
95.4%, and 96.1%, respectively.  
 
Discussion 
Qualitative error analysis identified a common source of inaccuracy, notably in cohort 
identification and categorization. Phase1/2 studies prioritize early indications of treatment 
efficacy, while phase 2/3 studies emphasize prolonged effects. Adverse event distribution is 
consistent across phases, with noticeable increases in fatal events in later phases, suggesting 
longer follow-up or more patients may reveal severe adverse events missed in phase 1 safety 
studies. 
 
Conclusion 
SEETrials displayed high accuracy and generalizability to diverse drug modalities and disease 
domains. Its capacity to streamline large-scale dataset analysis is crucial for advancing clinical 
trial research, ensuring timely and accurate data extraction, and facilitating efficient 
dissemination.

INTRODUCTION 
 
Effective clinical decision-making relies profoundly on the continuous flow of data and 
outcomes derived from clinical trial studies [1]. The timely dissemination of clinical trial 
outcomes, including risks and benefits from early-phase trials, holds importance in facilitating 
well-informed decision-making in patient care, ultimately influencing patient treatment outcomes 
[2]. Swift access to data also plays a critical role in optimizing patient recruitment for clinical 
trials, a pivotal factor in expediting the development of novel treatments, particularly in high-
need medical areas such as oncology [3].  
 
Conference abstracts often serve as crucial sources of preliminary findings, unveiling clinical 
trial results and providing insights into the efficacy and safety of investigational treatments. 
However, the retrieval of these abstracts poses a challenge, and trial results initially presented in 
the conference abstracts may not progress to subsequent journal publication [4]. This 
discrepancy is significant, with more than 50% of outcomes from abstracts and nearly one-third 
of randomized trial results, initially introduced in conference abstracts, failing to advance to full 
publication, and this trend has not shown improvement over time [5]. Moreover, despite the 
recommendation to include conference abstracts in systematic literature reviews by both 
Cochrane and the United States National Academy of Sciences [6], concerns persist regarding 
the unclear impact of unpublished conference abstracts on the final conclusions [7] and 
inconsistency between conference abstracts and papers in reporting results [8–10]. Given these 
various benefits and concerns, a complete and thorough systematic review requires clinical 
outcomes to be extracted not only from published articles but also from all conference abstracts. 
This approach allows for the generation of a comprehensive clinical evidence base and for 
gaining insights into the consistency between results from the conference and full paper 
abstracts. Nevertheless, extracting granular information from these sources with sufficient 
precision, particularly within the context of large-scale datasets, in a timely manner, poses an 
additional challenge.  
 
Natural Language Processing (NLP) has proven to be a transformative technology in the medical 
and clinical research domains, offering a significant advantage in extracting clinical data 
elements from unstructured free-text documents [11–13]. Recently, large language models 
(LLMs) have gained tremendous attention within the NLP domain, exhibiting remarkable 
capabilities in understanding context, reasoning, and processing vast amounts of textual 
information [14–16]. The introduction of more potent generative pre-trained transformer (GPT) 
models such as ChatGPT and GPT-4, have prompted a thorough investigation into their 
effectiveness across diverse medical applications.  
 
Within the realm of information extraction from clinical documents, various LLMs have been 
deployed in diverse applications, such as analyzing radiology reports [17–19] and electronic

health records [15]. In the clinical trial domain, LLMs play crucial roles in trial information 
retrieval [20], criteria text generation [21], and clinical trial eligibility criteria analysis [22].  
Despite recognized limitations, ChatGPT has also demonstrated value in supporting systematic 
literature reviews [23]. Notably, prior studies have not explored the application of these models 
for extracting clinical trial outcomes from conference abstracts, especially in scenarios involving 
dense information presented in both text and tables.  
 
In this study, we present "SEETrials," an innovative LLM pipeline designed to automatically 
extract safety and efficacy information from a substantial volume of conference and published 
journal abstracts related to multiple myeloma clinical trial studies. The significance of this study 
lies in addressing the challenge of extracting comprehensive information, especially from 
conference abstracts, which often contain condensed tables with crucial contents briefly 
described or left unspecified due to word limitations. Furthermore, we evaluated the 
generalizability of our system by applying it to three additional types of cancer clinical trial 
studies, assessing its effectiveness across diverse cancer research contexts. The overarching 
objective is to enhance the accessibility of timely and precise clinical data in a computable 
format for downstream analysis and synthesizing clinical evidence.

BACKGROUND  
 
Conference abstracts play a crucial role in generating evidence for clinical decision-making 
across diverse domains, but their dissemination is limited. Time lags from conference abstracts 
to full paper publication [4], and a low conversion rate from abstract to journal paper [9,24,25] 
contribute to this disparity. Various factors, including time constraints [26] hinder the 
publication of abstracts in full journals. Publication bias further compounds this issue, resulting 
in the underrepresentation of "not positive or negative" results or "positive but not statistically 
significant" results in publications [5,27,28] despite the significance of all study results in 
influencing clinical decision-making and patient care. Difficulties in extracting information from 
free-text formats also pose additional challenges.   
 
We focused on multiple myeloma clinical trial studies as a use case for development of our 
LLM model, recognizing the pressing need for timely and precise clinical data in this clinical 
context. Despite significant advancements in treatment options and survival rates over the last 
15 years, multiple myeloma remains an incurable malignancy, marked by elevated rates of 
relapse and therapy resistance [29]. Furthermore, the introduction of numerous new therapies 
has created significant uncertainty regarding therapy selection and sequencing, given the limited 
availability of consensus guidelines and recent systematic literature reviews [30,31]. Our 
analysis concentrated on the most recent mechanism of action drugs developed in the last decade 
to explore the feasibility of ensuring timely access to accurate clinical outcomes from both 
annual conference abstracts and published journal abstracts. Leveraging the resulting LLM 
pipeline should enhance clinical decision-making and facilitate patient recruitment in clinical 
trials.

MATERIALS AND METHODS 
 
Data 
 
For the model development and evaluation, we collected 100 clinical trial abstracts related to 
multiple myeloma from various drug groups, focusing on five different modalities. The sources 
included the American Society of Clinical Oncology (ASCO: https://ascopubs.org/jco/meeting ), 
American Society of Hematology conferences (ASH: 
https://ashpublications.org/blood/issue/142/Supplement%201 ), and PubMed 
(https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/ ) websites. The selection was based on keywords (“clinical 
trial” AND “each modality”). The modalities covered are  1) chimeric antigen receptor T cell 
therapy (CAR-T therapy) ; idecabtagene vicleucel and ciltacabtagene autoleucel, 2) Bispecific 
Antibodies (BsAbs)/Bispecific T cell engager (BiTE) therapy; talquetamab-tgvs, teclistamab-
cqyv, and elranatamab-bcmm, 3) Antibody-drug conjugates (ADC) therapy; Belantamab-
mafodotin, and 4) Cereblon E3 ligase modulator therapy (CELMoD) ; Iberdomide and 
Mezigdomide 5) Others abstracts including Histone deacetylase inhibitor (HDACi) and immune 
checkpoint inhibitors (ICI); pembrolizumab.   
 
For the prompt design phase, we used 20 abstracts, followed by 30 abstracts for prompt 
calibration. Subsequently, another set of 50 abstracts was employed for the system evaluation. 
"Prompt design" involved creating initial prompts through manual scrutiny of abstracts, while 
"prompt calibration" refined prompts iteratively based on expert evaluation of the system output, 
both guided by expert judgment (HP and KL). 
 
After establishing the system, we implemented the system on an additional 145 multiple 
myeloma clinical trial study abstracts for comprehensive data analysis, resulting in a total of 245 
abstracts used for the data analysis. To assess the generalizability of our system, we included 18 
additional clinical trial abstracts (6 related to breast cancer, 7 to non-small cell lung cancer, and 5 
to leukemia) sourced from PubMed. 
 
SEETrials 
 
We developed SEETrials to extract crucial details from clinical trial studies presented at annual 
conferences and published journal abstracts, leveraging the capabilities of GPT-4. The 
subsequent sections outline the components of the system and Figure 1 provides a schematic 
overview. 
 
Pre-processing steps for abstracts collection and table conversion  
 
We collected abstract texts from ASCO, ASH, and PubMed websites. Abstract texts from 
PubMed were directly saved in text format, while those from ASCO and ASH websites were 
All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission. 
(which was not certified by peer review) is the author/funder, who has granted medRxiv a license to display the preprint in perpetuity. 
The copyright holder for this preprintthis version posted January 20, 2024. ; https://doi.org/10.1101/2024.01.18.24301502doi: medRxiv preprint 
7 
initially captured in a Word file and later converted to a text file (UTF-8) to facilitate the 
efficient loading of a substantial number of abstracts for automated data extraction.  Notably, 
abstracts from annual conferences often contain tabular data structures, and the word to text file 
conversion process may lead to formatting issues or broken tables, creating challenges for GPT 
comprehension. To address potential formatting issues, we developed an "Automatic Table 
Organizer" module leveraging GPT, effectively realigning columns and rows. For ASH 
conference abstracts featuring tables in picture format, we applied Optical Character Recognition 
(OCR) to convert picture files into text files before employing the "Automatic Table Organizer" 
for further processing. Two input variations for abstracts with tables were then generated, one 
with the table included and one without. 
 
Knowledge ingestion 
 
SEETrials operates on a knowledge-driven framework and require foundational comprehension 
and knowledge of oncology and clinical trials. We did not presume that this knowledge was 
inherent in the GPT models we used. Rather we designed prompts to incorporate foundational 
comprehension and knowledge of oncology clinical trials. We also incorporated an 
understanding of their primary and secondary endpoints for efficacy and safety outcome 
measurement.  
 
Prompt modeling for data extraction and merging outcomes 
 
We directed our GPT system to extract and align information related to cohort composition. To 
enhance GPT performance and output accuracy, we employed two distinct GPT modules for 
each of the comprehensive prompts: one for "Individual cohorts/arms and entire group" and 
another for " Individual cohorts/arms and subgroup group".  
 
Each prompt included three main components: a general instruction to extract study details, 
clinical safety and efficacy outcomes; the abstract text; and a query. The query explicitly 
requested information on entities and values for specific tables, with detailed instructions for 
formatting.  
 
The outputs from both modules were combined in the subsequent step, where we merged outputs 
from the "Individual cohorts/arms and entire group" and " Individual cohorts/arms and subgroup 
group" modules. This merging process employed a prompt to accurately combine extracted 
entities and values and eliminate any overlaps.  
 
To finalize the output format, we transferred the results to csv file. In this file, each entity was 
represented in individual rows, and associated values for each cohort, entire group, or subgroup 
were organized in columns to facilitate further downstream analysis.

Postprocessing 
 
We implemented a post-processing module to refine outputs from the data extracting module by 
addressing two key formatting challenges: (1) addressing undesired allocations of entities and 
their corresponding values in the outputs and (2) ensuring that each cell within the value’s 
column contained a singular value, optimizing the presentation for computational analysis.  
 
Evaluation 
For the system assessment, we used 50 randomly selected abstracts, manually annotated by 
knowledge experts (KL, NO, and HP). The evaluation was conducted in two ways: a strict 
approach and a relaxed approach. In the strict evaluation, entities and their values, whether in a 
single arm or multiple arms, were treated as a unified entity. Any inaccuracies or omissions in 
values across different arms, were considered as false positives or false negatives or both for 
each entity (each row in the output file). In the relaxed evaluation, entities and values for each 
arm were assessed independently (each cell in the output file). We presented the precision, recall, 
and F1 scores of SEETrials for each abstract, considering both strict and relaxed evaluations. 
 
Descriptive Data Analysis  
  
The Descriptive Data Analysis initiated with the normalization of extracted entities, converting 
terms such as "OSR" to "Overall Survival Rate (OSR)" for standardization. Subsequently, the 
total occurrences of entities across diverse modalities were tabulated, leading to the creation of a 
master data file. We examined the distribution and a quantitative overview of entities, 
specifically emphasizing treatment efficacy and safety, in conjunction with trial phases.

RESULTS 
 
Establishment and Evaluation of the LLM System, SEETrials 
 
Recognizing potential formatting challenges in abstracts with tables, we developed an 
"Automatic Table Organizer" GPT module. This module effectively realigned columns and rows 
in the text file, rectifying any formatting discrepancies. Following the application of the 
Automatic Table Organizer, we observed improved table information extraction but noted a 
decrease in performance for extracting main body text information (data not shown). To address 
this, we input two abstract sets into our GPT system: one with organized tables and the other 
without tables. The outcomes from two different input sets were combined in the Merging 
module. 
 
The performance evaluation of SEETrials, conducted on a subset of 50 selected abstracts, is 
delineated in Table 1. The system demonstrated a high level of precision, recall, and F1 score, 
with an overall performance of 95.5%, 93.9%, and 94.7%, respectively, across all Mechanisms 
of Action (MOAs) in strict evaluation. In the relaxed evaluation, the system exhibited an even 
higher performance, achieving an overall precision of 98.1%, a recall of 98.9%, and an F1 score 
of 98.5%. Comprehensive details, including the total number of entities, and values counted, as 
well as true positive, false positive, and false negative numbers, are provided in the 
supplementary Table 1.

Qualitative Error Analysis 
 
We conducted a qualitative error analysis on individual documents, presenting our findings from 
the abstracts with F1 scores lower than 80% (4/50 abstracts, # 20, 37, 46, and 50) in Figure 2.  
 
• Case 1 (#20) is a phase 1 dose-escalation study determining the recommended phase 2 
dosage (RP2D). It included information on the entire cohort and intervention dosage. 
However, data for treatment outcomes, including safety and efficacy, were derived from 
a small portion of the RP2D group. The values were redundantly presented for both the 
entire group and the RP2D cohort (Figure 2A). 
 
• Case 2 (#37) represents a dose escalation study (trial phase information was not 
specified). The study comprises four distinct arms, each associated with a different 
dosage. Despite the abstract's mention of these four arms and the investigational drug 
dosage for each, the cohort size and study findings outlined in the abstract pertain to the 
combined cohorts 1 and 2, specifically the lowest two doses. Notably, SEETrials 
erroneously presented identical information for both cohort 1 and cohort 2, resulting in a 
uniform cohort size of 6 for each (Figure 2B). 
 
 
• Case 3 (#46) introduces a phase 1 dose-escalation study featuring two arms, each linked 
to a different dosage. The abstract provides information on cohort size and treatment 
outcomes for the overall group, as well as individual details for Arm 1 and Arm 2. 
Furthermore, the abstract introduces specific information about dose escalation 
subgroups, encompassing cohort size and response rates. While SEETrials accurately 
predicted most entities and values for the entire cohort and Arms 1 and 2, it did not 
capture information about the dose escalation subgroups (Figure 2C). 
 
• Case 4 (#50) is a phase 3 study with one control arm and three intervention arms with an 
investigated drug at three different dosages. SEETrials accurately extracted information 
for the three intervention arms but missed details on the control arm. This led to all 
clinical finding entities being considered false negatives in STRICT evaluation (F1 
76%), though in RELAXED evaluation, the overall performance was higher (F1 96%) 
due to correct extraction for the three intervention arms (Figure 2D).  
 
As described, a prevalent source of inaccuracy in the extraction process pertains to cohort 
identification and categorization. Abstracts frequently encompass diverse clinical information for 
multiple cohorts, including Dose-escalation, Dose-expansion, RP2D groups, entire groups, and 
subgroups. The lack of explicit descriptions in the text occasionally poses a challenge for the

The copyright holder for this preprintthis version posted January 20, 2024. ; https://doi.org/10.1101/2024.01.18.24301502doi: medRxiv preprint

system in determining the appropriate allocation of values. Additionally, our observations 
revealed the presence of other errors in the extraction process. 
 
• Author’s affiliation information in PubMed abstracts was extracted and used as the study 
location in cases where actual study location was not mentioned in the abstracts. 
 
• Cohort size discrepancies arise when the initial abstract mentions a specific size (e.g., 
n=14) but describes outcomes for a different number (e.g., n=10). Lack of clarification 
about the missing patients in the cohort further complicates allocation, leading to 
occasional misplacement of entities and values. 
 
• GPT occasionally captures only the percentage value (e.g., 25%) without extracting other 
relevant information (e.g., 14 patients). To ensure output consistency, improvement is 
needed for extracting all values and allocating them into separate cells.

Analyzing Extracted Entities from Abstracts 
 
We curated a comprehensive dataset comprising 245 abstracts, covering diverse therapeutic 
modalities. This includes 130 abstracts related to CAR-T cell therapies, 63 to BsAbs/BiTE 
therapies, 38 to ADC therapies, 6 to CELMoD therapies, 4 to HDACi therapies, and 4 to ICI 
therapies. Among these, there were 75, 47, 46, and 16 abstracts corresponding to phases 1, 1/2, 2, 
and 3. 61 abstracts did not have phase information. The distribution of clinical trial phases in 
each modality is detailed in Table 2. 
 
Table 3 and Supplemental Table 2 present the descriptive statistics of extracted clinical 
outcomes, focusing on treatment effectiveness and safety across three distinct modalities. 
The complete list of extracted data elements was detailed in Figure 3.  Notably, the overall 
response rate emerged as the most frequently reported entity related to treatment efficacy in 
clinical trial abstracts, with percentages of 23.9% in CAR T studies, 27.3% in BsAbs/BiTE 
studies, and 25% in ADC studies. Complete response rates were prominent, particularly in CAR 
T studies at 21.8% and in BsAbs//BiTE studies at 15.4%. Similarly, (very good) partial 
responses were noteworthy in ADC studies, accounting for 20% of the mentions. 
The entity of minimal residual disease featured prominently in CAR T cell therapy clinical trial 
abstracts (8%), surpassing mentions in BsAbs/BiTE (3.5%) and ADC (2.5%) studies. 
 
Examining safety-related entities, neutropenia emerged as the most frequently mentioned 
adverse event across all three modalities, with percentages of 13.4% in CAR T, 13.5% in 
BsAbs//BiTE, and 12.4% in ADC studies. Cytokine release syndrome was prevalent, with rates 
of 13.0% in CAR T, 9% in BsAbs//BiTE, and 8.6% in ADC studies. Thrombocytopenia and 
anemia were also commonly cited adverse events across modalities, showing variations in 
percentages. Infection occurrences were noted in 4.8% of CAR T studies, while higher 
percentages of 12% and 8.6% were observed in BsAbs/BiTE and ADC studies, respectively. 
 
Figure 4 provides a visual summary of the percentages of 11 efficacy and safety-related entities 
across the three modalities, offering a comprehensive overview of the comparative landscape. 
These findings contribute to a deeper understanding of the distinct clinical profiles associated 
with CAR T cell therapy, BsAbs/BiTE, and ADC modalities, facilitating informed decision-
making in therapeutic development.

In Figures 5 and 6, we present a detailed breakdown of trial numbers and percentages stratified 
by clinical trial phases (phases 1, 1/2, 2, and 3) for efficacy and safety-related entities, 
respectively. Notably, response rates and status-related entities were frequently reported in phase 
1 studies, indicating a focus on early indications of treatment efficacy. Conversely, survival or 
treatment duration-related entities were predominantly extracted in phase 2 studies, highlighting 
a shift towards assessing prolonged treatment effects and overall therapeutic impact. 
 
The distribution of adverse event entities exhibited consistency across different phases of 
clinical trials. Only noticeable differences were observed in fatal adverse events which appear 
significantly more in later phase trials compared to phase 1 initial study. This observation 
suggests that longer follow-up times and or increased number of patients can show more severe 
grade of adverse events that were not detected in phase 1 safety study.

Evaluating the Generalizability of the System 
 
We implemented our system on randomly chosen cancer clinical trial studies, including two solid 
cancers (breast cancer and lung cancer) and one hematologic cancer (leukemia). The performance 
scores across 18 abstracts are highly consistent with both each o ther and the earlier 50 multiple 
abstracts (refer to Table 4). The average precision, recall, and F1 score s in strict evaluation were 
96.9%, 95.4%, and 96.1%, respectively. Comprehensive details, including the total number of 
entities, and values counted, as well as true positive, false positive, and false negative numbers, in 
these 18 abstract analyses, are provided in the supplementary Table 2.

DISCUSSION 
 
In the development of our knowledge-driven system, SEETrials, our primary aim was the 
systematic extraction of clinical trial study details and treatment outcomes and their 
corresponding values automatically, from abstracts of multiple myeloma clinical trial studies. 
This encompassed both conference abstracts and published article abstracts. Our study 
significantly contributes by strategically addressing the challenge of extracting comprehensive 
information, particularly from conference abstracts. These abstracts often present condensed 
tables, where crucial content is concisely summarized or left unspecified in the main text due to 
word limitations. Moreover, our study significantly improved the accessibility of timely and 
precise clinical data in a computable format for downstream data analysis.  
 
The implementation of "SEETrials" demonstrated remarkable potential, evidenced by high 
precision, recall, and F1 scores of 95.5%, 93.9%, and 94.7%, respectively. These robust 
performance metrics serve as a validation of the efficacy of our pipeline in the accurate 
extraction of detailed information from multiple myeloma clinical trial studies. Additionally, this 
study systematically explored the zero-shot capabilities of GPT-4 [20,32], particularly in tasks 
such as interventions and the recognition of treatment outcome entities. These tasks included the 
association of outcomes with corresponding values in each cohort and the classification of 
cohorts, all seamlessly executed through the use of efficiently designed single-turn prompts. 
Notably, our findings underscored the adaptability of a comprehensive prompt initially tailored 
for a specific cancer clinical trial (e.g., Multiple Myeloma) to successfully extract trial 
information from diverse cancer types (e.g., breast cancer, lung cancer, and leukemia). This 
observation underscores the expansive applicability of SEETrials, ensuring the uniform analysis 
of clinical trial study outcomes across diverse disease domains. Consequently, this enhances 
analysis efficiency, scalability, and interoperability within the field. To our knowledge, this 
study marks a pioneering attempt to explore the zero-shot capabilities of a GPT-powered model 
for the comprehensive extraction of clinical trial study outcomes from various types of abstracts, 
in addition to our previously established system—a generalizable clinical trial eligibility criteria 
extraction system powered by a large language model [22].  
 
In this study, we analyzed a range of drug modalities within the framework of multiple 
myeloma, with specific emphasis on CAR-T, BsAbs/BiTE, ADCs, and CELMoD therapies. The 
examination of treatment efficacy and safety outcome distributions across diverse drug 
modalities and trial phases yielded valuable insights. A thorough understanding of how these 
outcomes vary across different modalities and phases is crucial for contextualizing clinical trial 
results. Notably, phase 1 studies exhibit a prevalence of response rates and status-related entities, 
highlighting an emphasis on early indicators of treatment efficacy while phase 2 studies have 
more survival or treatment duration-related entities, indicating an evolving focus on prolonged 
treatment effects and overall therapeutic impact as trials progress. Our study aligns with existing

literature, revealing differences in infection occurrences among different modalities, reflecting 
consistent safety profiles in CAR T studies, BsAbs/BiTE studies, and ADC studies [33,34]. 
Interestingly, our analysis indicates notable differences in the incidence of fatal adverse events 
between later phase trials and the initial phase 1 study. The increased prevalence of fatal adverse 
events in later phases raises considerations regarding the dynamics of safety assessments over 
time. A plausible explanation is the potential manifestation of more severe grades of adverse 
events with longer follow-up times and an increased number of enrolled patients. This suggests 
that certain adverse events, particularly those of a more critical nature, may not be readily 
apparent during early clinical development, emphasizing the critical importance of extended 
follow-up periods and larger patient cohorts. While phase 1 studies provide crucial insights into 
initial safety profiles, the evolution of adverse events, particularly those with fatal outcomes, 
becomes more apparent in subsequent phases. Therefore, these observed differences underscore 
the need for sustained vigilance and thorough monitoring in later phases to capture and address 
adverse events that may emerge with prolonged exposure or in a broader patient population. 
 
While this study did not place significant emphasis on certain aspects, future work could delve 
into critical details such as previous treatment history (e.g., the percentage of patients with a 
different prior line of therapy, specific numbers like "triple-class refractory" multiple myeloma), 
the percentage of high-risk cytogenetics or other high risk group patients, or the percentage of 
patients with specific biomarkers (e.g., PD-1 or mismatch repair status etc.) enrolled in the study 
for more in-depth analysis. We also would like to expand the adaptability in various conference 
abstracts in future study. Furthermore, the feasibility test comparing treatment outcomes in 
earlier conference abstracts and subsequent full articles leveraging SEETrials’ potential can 
address community inquiries. Concerns about reporting accuracy in conference abstracts arise 
from the lack of elaborate peer-reviews unlike publications [7].  
 
CONCLUSION 
 
We developed SEETrials, a GPT-based system with broad applicability, capable of identifying 
granular safety and efficacy entities across various clinical trial studies. The system 
demonstrated high precision, recall, and F1, affirming its reliability and accuracy. SEETrials 
shows significant potential in ensuring timely and accurate data extraction and facilitating 
efficient dissemination of clinical trial outcomes.
